section.p: Javadoc has been around for ever, and is a general tool for generating API documentation. Probably every Java coder would have used it at some time, and would normally just provide the minimal arguments to generate HTML output. At Java 1.4, its was updated to handle generics and annotations, at java 1.7, there has been some style sheet changes, but we also know that there are going to be some internal changes to Javadoc. One of the main changes is that currently, there is a restriction that Javadoc can only be run once within a JVM. This is not normally an issue as its run from the command line or ant task, but does make testing difficult. At Java 1.8, there are also going to be some internal changes to the way taglets and doclets will work and a general move to the javax.lang.model.

One of the big issues with Javadoc is its woeful lack of error reporting, this is currently understood by the Oracle Javadoc team and may in future, get better. We understand that as of 1.8, HTML syntax checking is available.
